title: Siege of Esztergom (1543)
text:
The siege of Esztergom occurred between 25 July and 10 August 1543, when the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="Military_of_the_Ottoman_Empire">army</a>, led by Sultan <a href="Suleiman%20the%20Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, besieged the city of <a href="Esztergom">Esztergom</a> in modern <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>. The city was captured by the Ottomans after two weeks.
Background.
The siege was part of a struggle between the <a href="Habsburgs">Habsburgs</a> and the Ottomans following the death of the ruler of Hungary, <a href="John%20Z%C3%A1polya">John Zápolya</a>, on 20 July 1540. This is part of the "Age of castle wars" in Hungarian history. Suleiman had captured the cities of <a href="Buda">Buda</a> and <a href="Pest%2C%20Hungary">Pest</a> in 1541, giving him a powerful control over central Hungary. The Province ("<a href="Beylerbey">Beylerbeylik</a>") of Buda was created in this occasion. 
As part of the <a href="Franco-Ottoman%20alliance">Franco-Ottoman alliance</a>, French troops were supplied to this Ottoman campaign in Hungary: a French artillery unit was dispatched in 1543-1544 and attached to the <a href="Ottoman%20Army">Ottoman Army</a>. Meanwhile, in the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>, Suleiman had sent his <a href="fleet%20admiral">fleet admiral</a> <a href="Hayreddin%20Barbarossa">Hayreddin Barbarossa</a> to cooperate with the French, leading to the <a href="siege%20of%20Nice">siege of Nice</a>.
Siege.
The Siege of Esztergom followed the failed attempt by <a href="Ferdinand%20I%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Ferdinand I of Austria</a> to recapture <a href="Buda">Buda</a> in 1542. It would be followed in turn by the capture of the Hungarian coronation city of <a href="Sz%C3%A9kesfeh%C3%A9rv%C3%A1r">Székesfehérvár</a> in September 1543. Other cities that were captured during this campaign are <a href="Sikl%C3%B3s">Siklós</a> and <a href="Szeged">Szeged</a> in order to better protect <a href="Buda">Buda</a>. However, Suleiman refrained from moving further on to <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a> this time, apparently because he had no news of the campaigns of his French allies in western Europe and in the Mediterranean.
After the successful Ottoman campaign, a first truce of one year was signed with Charles V in 1545, through the intermediary of <a href="Francis%20I%20of%20France">Francis I of France</a>. Suleiman himself was interested in ending the hostilities, as he had a campaign going on in Persia as well, the <a href="Ottoman%E2%80%93Safavid%20War%20%281532%E2%80%931555%29">Ottoman–Safavid War (1532–1555)</a>. Two years later, Ferdinand and <a href="Charles%20V%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Charles V</a> recognized total Ottoman control of Hungary in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Adrianople%20%281547%29">1547 Treaty of Adrianople</a>, and Ferdinand even agreed to pay a yearly <a href="tribute">tribute</a> of 30,000 gold florins for their <a href="Habsburg">Habsburg</a> possessions in northern and western Hungary.
Following these conquests, central <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a> was to remain under Ottoman control until 1686.
